conclusion: On a v–t diagram the acceleration a(t) is the slope (tangent) of the curve at each instant.

In both curves (A and B) the tangent at t = 0 is steep and positive, then becomes progressively less steep, is zero at the peak velocity, and finally becomes negative as the curve slopes downward back to v = 0 at t = t₁.
The slope—and therefore the acceleration—steadily decreases from a positive value, passes through zero, and becomes negative.
At no stage does the slope increase before it decreases.
No. For both objects the acceleration continually decreases (from positive to zero to negative); it is not “first increasing and then decreasing.”
